question: What was the major trans-regional route towards the southern part of India called in the 6th century BCE?
explanation: The two major trans-regional routes of the 6<sup>th</sup> century were known as Uttarapatha and Dakshinapatha. Dakshinapatha for southern India, stretching from Pataliputra in Magadha to Pratishthana on the Godavari and connected to ports on the western coast.
